A1: simple past with regular verbs (walked, played)
simple past with common irregular verbs (went, had, was)
basic prepositions of place (in, on, at, under)
basic prepositions of time (in, on, at)
subject pronouns and possessive adjectives (I/my, he/his)
A2: simple future with will and going to
comparatives and superlatives (bigger, the most beautiful)
countable / uncountable nouns (much, many, a few, a little)
adverbs of frequency (always, usually, sometimes, never)
present perfect simple with ever, never, just, already, yet
infinitive of purpose (to + verb: I went to the store to buy milk)
B1: first conditional (If it rains, I will stay home)
second conditional (If I had money, I would travel)
passive voice - present and past (is made, was built)
relative clauses with who, which, that, where
used to + infinitive (I used to play tennis)
modals of deduction: must, might, can't (She must be tired)
gerund vs infinitive (enjoy doing, want to do)
so / such (so tired, such a good idea)
B2: third conditional (If I had studied, I would have passed)
mixed conditionals (If I had left earlier, I would be there now)
wish + past simple / past perfect (I wish I knew, I wish I had known)
passive voice - all tenses including modals (should be done, might have been taken)
causative: have/get something done (I had my car repaired)
as long as, provided that, unless, in case
once / after / as soon as + present for future (Once you finish, call me)
phrasal verbs in context (give up, look into, come across)
C1: subjunctive (It's essential that he be present)
inversion after negative adverbials (Not only did he..., Never have I...)
inversion in conditionals (Had I known..., Were it not for...)
cleft sentences (It was John who..., What I need is...)
passive causative (had it repaired vs got it stolen)
advanced wish structures (If only I hadn't...)
participle clauses (Having finished the work, she left)
fronting for emphasis (Rarely do we see..., Little did they know...)
formal subjunctive (I suggest that he leave)
complex noun phrases (The decision taken by the committee last week...)
hedging language (It would appear that..., There seems to be...)
distancing (is said to be, is believed to have)
C2: ellipsis and substitution (I think so, If so, If not)
advanced inversion patterns (So spectacular was the view that...)
nominalization (the destruction of, the failure to comply)
advanced modality (need not have done, might well have been)
complex hypothetical structures (But for his help, we would have failed)
archaic/literary subjunctive (Be that as it may, Come what may)
double comparatives (The more you practice, the better you get)
concessive clauses (Much as I admire him, ...)
